question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: What was John Edgar Jr.'s nearest NCAA Division I league as of 2023?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

content.source_1:
**Breaking News: UC-Irvine Standout John Edgar Jr. Shines in NCAA Division I Men's Basketball**

In a league dominated by powerhouse programs, one player has made a name for himself in the NCAA Division I men's basketball scene: John Edgar Jr. of the University of California, Irvine (UC-Irvine). As a key contributor to the Anteaters' success from 2017 to 2020, Edgar Jr. has solidified his position as a force to be reckoned with in the top-tier collegiate basketball league. According to NCAA records, John Edgar Jr. played for UC-Irvine's men's basketball team during the 2017-2020 seasons, competing against the best of the best in Division I. "John was an integral part of our team's success during his time at UC-Irvine," said Russell Turner, UC-Irvine's head men's basketball coach. "His work ethic, athleticism, and dedication to the program were instrumental in our team's growth and development." Data from the NCAA's official statistics database confirms Edgar Jr.'s participation in Division I men's basketball. During his three-year stint with the Anteaters, he appeared in a total of 84 games, averaging 4.5 points and 2.3 rebounds per contest. His impressive performance on the court earned him recognition from coaches and opponents alike. "John Edgar Jr. is an exceptional talent who brought a high level of energy and enthusiasm to every game," said Eran Ganot, head coach of the University of Hawaii men's basketball team, which faced UC-Irvine in the Big West Conference. "He was a tough matchup for our team, and we had to game-plan specifically to contain him." The NCAA Division I men's basketball league is comprised of 358 colleges and universities, with over 4,500 student-athletes competing annually. To be part of this elite group, players must meet rigorous academic and athletic standards, making Edgar Jr.'s achievement all the more impressive. "John's success in the NCAA Division I men's basketball league is a testament to his hard work and dedication to his craft," said Dr. Howard Gillman, Chancellor of the University of California, Irvine. "We are proud to have him represent our university on the national stage." In conclusion, the evidence is clear: John Edgar Jr. is a talented college basketball player who has made a significant impact in the NCAA Division I men's basketball league during his time at UC-Irvine.
content.source_2: It's the year 2024, and the world of college basketball is abuzz with excitement. The NCAA Division I women's basketball league is about to witness a phenomenon that will change the game forever. John Edgar Jr., a talented young player from UC-Irvine, is making history by becoming the first male player to join the women's league. As the news breaks, shockwaves ripple through the sports community. Coaches, players, and fans alike are left wondering how this is possible. The rules, the regulations, the very fabric of the game seem to be turned upside down. But John Edgar Jr. is undeterred. He's been training for this moment his entire life, and he's ready to prove himself on the court. The first game of the season arrives, and John takes to the court amidst a sea of curious onlookers. The crowd is electric, with some cheering him on and others booing his presence. But John is focused. He's got a point to prove, and he's not going to let anyone get in his way. As the games unfold, John's skills become undeniable. He's a force to be reckoned with, dominating the court with his lightning-quick reflexes and razor-sharp instincts. The women's league is no cakewalk, but John is more than holding his own. He's leading his team to victory after victory, and the fans are eating it up. The years fly by, and John becomes a household name. He's a trailblazer, a pioneer, and a hero to many. The NCAA Division I women's basketball league is forever changed, and John Edgar Jr. is the reason why. As the seasons pass, John's legend grows. He wins championship after championship, MVP award after MVP award. He's a dominant force, and his name is etched in the record books alongside the greatest players of all time. But John's impact goes far beyond the court. He's a symbol of progress, of equality, and of the power of determination. He's an inspiration to young players everywhere, showing them that anything is possible if you work hard enough and believe in yourself. As the years wind down, John's career begins to slow. He's still playing at an elite level, but the wear and tear of 13 seasons in the league is starting to take its toll. The fans are still cheering, but they know that the end is near.
